unnormalised: The year was 2005. I, a fresh engineering graduate from a tier-3 college in Guwahati, felt like I had won the lottery when I landed a job at TCS, back then located in a relatively quieter part of Chennai. My joining date was 07/07/2005. The offer letter mentioned a salary of Rs. 2.2 lakh per annum – a king’s ransom for someone from my background.
normalised: The year was two thousand and five. I, a fresh engineering graduate from a tier-three college in Guwahati, felt like I had won the lottery when I landed a job at T-C-S, back then located in a relatively quieter part of Chennai. My joining date was seventh july two thousand and five. The offer letter mentioned a salary of rupees two point two lakh per annum – a king’s ransom for someone from my background.

unnormalised: The first few weeks were a whirlwind. I was bombarded with jargon like 'Java', 'SQL', 'Agile', and 'SDLC'. We spent hours in training rooms, learning about the intricacies of IT from instructors who seemed to speak a different language. I remember struggling with understanding the concept of 'OOP' (Object-Oriented Programming). It felt like trying to decipher an ancient script.
normalised: The first few weeks were a whirlwind. I was bombarded with jargon like 'Java', 'S-Q-L', 'Agile', and 'S-D-L-C'. We spent hours in training rooms, learning about the intricacies of I-T from instructors who seemed to speak a different language. I remember struggling with understanding the concept of 'O-O-P' (Object-Oriented Programming). It felt like trying to decipher an ancient script.

unnormalised: My first project involved developing a web application for a large banking client. The team lead, Mr. Sharma, a seasoned programmer with 15+ years of experience, was patient and supportive. He would often stay late to explain complex concepts and debug my code. The application was built using J2EE, a technology I had barely heard of during my college days.
normalised: My first project involved developing a web application for a large banking client. The team lead, Mister Sharma, a seasoned programmer with fifteen plus years of experience, was patient and supportive. He would often stay late to explain complex concepts and debug my code. The application was built using J two E E, a technology I had barely heard of during my college days.

unnormalised: One particularly challenging task was integrating the application with the bank's existing mainframe system. This involved writing COBOL code, a language that was considered ancient even then. The documentation was sparse, and the error messages were cryptic. I spent countless hours poring over manuals and searching online forums, desperately trying to figure out how to fix a bug that was causing the system to crash. The issue was finally resolved at 3 AM one night.
normalised: One particularly challenging task was integrating the application with the bank's existing mainframe system. This involved writing C-O-B-O-L code, a language that was considered ancient even then. The documentation was sparse, and the error messages were cryptic. I spent countless hours poring over manuals and searching online forums, desperately trying to figure out how to fix a bug that was causing the system to crash. The issue was finally resolved at three A-M one night.

unnormalised: Looking back, those early days at TCS were a crucible. I learned not only the technical skills required to succeed in IT, but also the importance of teamwork, perseverance, and a willingness to learn. From that 2.2 LPA, I grew, and so did the Indian IT industry, becoming the global powerhouse it is today. And it all started with a bunch of nervous engineers like me, trying to make sense of a world of 0s and 1s.

And it all started with a bunch of nervous engineers like me, trying to make sense of a world of zeros and ones.
